block.p: The World Series between the Mets and the Yankees, the first Subway Series since 1956, gets under way tonight at Yankee Stadium after days of anticipation and desperate searches for tickets. Inside is a detailed look at how the two teams got this far.
PIAZZA UNMASKED -- Mike Piazza, the Mets' All-Star catcher, will not be behind the plate in Game 1. He will be the designated hitter and Todd Pratt will be the Mets' catcher.

NEW YORK, 1956 -- Back then, there were day games, the cold war, neighborhood loyalty, invisible masses. The Subway Series of 1956 was played in a city very different from today's.
LEADING OFF -- The two leadoff hitters, the Yankees' Chuck Knoblauch and the Mets' Timo Perez, have different backgrounds, styles and psyches about the game.

THE MANAGERS -- Once upon a time, long, long ago, Joe Torre managed the Mets and released a player named Bobby Valentine. Now the fiery Valentine and the laid-back Torre are colleagues with more in common than many might imagine.

ON THE MOUND -- The Yankees' Andy Pettitte and Roger Clemens credit an off-season regimen for their postseason success. The Mets' Mike Hampton has found his rhythm just as he may be making his final start for the team.
